content:
Floating point error 3 Validator Validator 
expected output is incorrect

For input 
```
2
-67 96 -82 -13
40 32 47 69
```
Output will be
```
1
-384.813 -2213.438
```
since intersection point is `-384.8125 -2213.4375` which can't be rounded to expected output using 'round-half-to-even' strategy (default for Python3) which is not mentioned in task description.
I have added three pairs of cases to make it easier to debug floating-point errors.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: ✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is very straightforward and includes many unique test cases. Good work!
Added the constraint for variable K
I think you should put something about outputting only a 0 if there are no intersections

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is very straightforward and includes many unique test cases. Good work!
This puzzle looks great! For a quick change, add a test case where perfectly horizontal/vertical lines are involved (aka 0 or unidentified slopes). Prove me wrong if this already exists.
Thank you, contribution updated. Added two more test cases.
OK, thank you. I changed the difficulty and description, also added more tests to cover edge cases.

Input
* Please add "space-separated" before "integers".

* Please change "[x1,y1]" to "([[x1]], [[y1]])".

* Please change "[x2,y2]" to "([[x2]], [[y2]])".

* Please follow up the second suggestion from @User123.

Output
* Please add "space-separated" before "real numbers".

* Please replace "Output points … ascending" with:

Output the points in ascending order, sorted by x-coordinate and then by y-coordinate.

* Please change "digits" to "decimal places".

Constraints
* Please add:
No two given line segments lie on the same straight line in a way that causes them to overlap at one or more points.

Cases
* Are there any cases with line segments that lie on the same straight line but do not overlap (e.g. one segment is 0 1 0 0 and the other is 0 4 0 6)? If not, consider adding such cases.

Thanks.

Nice puzzle :) Some suggestions from me:

- I think you can afford to omit details in the problem description and simply state: "You are given a set of lines in a 2D (x-y) plane. Your task is to find all the intersection points of these lines." Players can figure out the other details (count multiple intersections once) later in the test cases.

- Please move "All points are guaranteed to be distinct within a line." into the constraints section and rephrase it as "For each given line, [[[x1]], [[y1]]] ≠ [[[x2]], [[y2]]]." Please also add "Each pair of [[x1]], [[y1]], [[x2]], [[y2]] is distinct."

- Not sure if this should be a Medium puzzle; nested looping over all pairs of lines seems too brute-force to be a Medium. Maybe you could start by generating test cases where N is much larger than 10 (say, N = 500?) and see whether there is room for some form of optimization that might make this puzzle harder.

Regarding the first suggestion, I agree that brevity is important, but I believe the included details are necessary to avoid ambiguity. Clarifying whether the objects are line segments or infinite lines, and stating that identical intersection points should be counted only once, directly affects how the problem is interpreted and solved.

Relying on test cases to infer these rules can lead to confusion or inconsistent assumptions, whereas a clear statement ensures that all solvers are addressing the same well-defined task. As written, the description is still concise while specifying the essential elements of the task.

I agree with the second suggestion.

Concerning the difficulty level, I also think the puzzle may be slightly easier than Medium; either lowering the classification to Easy or increasing the task’s difficulty would be reasonable.

Thanks for the update. I took another look at the revised contribution and have a few small, mostly wording-related suggestions:

Goal / Input
* The puzzle can still be misinterpreted as referring to line segments (I initially did so myself). To make it explicit that these are infinite lines, consider adding the word "infinite":

  • Goal: after "set of".
  
  • Input: after "one".

Output
* Please change "count" to "output".

* Please remove the sentence: "Two coincident straight lines are parallel => Two coincident straight lines have no intersection (just for this puzzle).".

* After "infinite number of intersection points", please add:

However, for the purpose of this puzzle, coincident straight lines are treated as parallel and no intersection point should be output.

Cases
* Please add a new pair of cases, and in each case all scenarios are present (parallel lines, coincident lines, perpendicular lines, and other intersecting lines).

Thanks again.
It already exist in these test cases: "Two intersects", "Square", "Square crossed", "10 lines", "All cases", "Star"
Thank You.
OK, thank you, I added the constraint for variable K. I think this should be enough. Everybody can read the Output section and can see the appropriate test cases. "0" is normal integer value.
Thank You. And Merry Christmas :-)
Thank You. And Merry Christmas :-)
Could @Bazek or @kozuechan please follow up the issue mentioned by @StaS above? Thanks.

I apologize for the confusion. Strictly speaking, the problem statement should be unambiguous and the reference solution should produce correct outputs for any valid input. Since I added the test cases assuming the reference solution was correct and am now unsure of the author's original intent, I have removed the new test cases so that borderline solutions can pass. It would be great if the original author could provide some clarification.
Thank you for notifying me. I have taken a look.
@ArafatCoder, do you think you can write your own reasons instead of copying from others every single time?
Thank you, contribution updated.

Thanks @5DN1L, perhaps I wasn't specific in my first suggestion, but hopefully the puzzle description as edited by @Bazek is clearer now.

Typically in geometry, a line is associated with an infinite line and not a line segment; however, I do agree with the clarification to include "infinite line" in this puzzle.

I had earlier missed that pairs of x1, y1, x2, y2 can be distinct yet denote the same (coincident) infinite line. Instead of a special note that coincident lines should be treated as parallel and non-intersecting, would it be better to clarify (maybe in the input section?) that:

"If multiple rows of input [[x1]] [[y1]] [[x2]] [[y2]] define the same line, treat these inputs as just one line. E.g. input rows (0, 0, 1, 1), (1, 1, 2, 2), and (2, 2, 3, 3) should point to the same line y = x."
How about changing "parallel" to "the same line"?
I think either one is fine; my suggestion is just to reframe the input description such that it doesn't feel as if the player needs to make "special considerations" for coincident lines.

I see what you're aiming for. I think this case is inherently a special consideration: coincident lines do intersect in infinitely many points, so without an explicit note, a strict interpretation of the statement would imply that an infinite set of intersection points needs to be output. I'm leaning towards keeping the note explicit (either in the Goal section or the Output section).

On a related note, when you have a chance, could you take a look at the puzzle "Mountain range"? I'd really appreciate your thoughts.
